text: Hi, anyone know how I can implement the e commerce of google analytics, I try implemented but don't track the information

Mentioned this in <#C960Q64G4|design-manager> but need some help if anyone has any ideas :bulb: 

<https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/C960Q64G4/p1566228091170200>

Does anyone know if it is possible to set a different favicon for pages using a specific template? I tried adding a new favicon link to the head of the template but that didn't seem to do anything. Any tips are appreciated!
HubSpot does change the icon in the tab when there are notifications right?
so it should be possible
True but I'd rather it loaded in by default verses being changed dynamically with JS or something
<https://codepad.co/snippet/changing-your-site-s-favicon-with-javascript>
That works for the pages themselves (which is better than nothing if thats all that can be done) but when the favicon is being pulled in on other sites for example its not working
which im assuming is because its being changed by JS

I haven't run specifically into this in regards to HubSpot, but anytime you want to inject something into an existing action, I always make sure to disable the current action first, then do my action, then continue with the default action. For example, a browser will complete its navigation to a new page ASAP and not wait for an ajax call to start or complete (odd results). But if you disable the default action on click, then do your push, and only if that completes (or you give it a timeout/proceed) then you can have the link continue.
Is there any way to know when the event has successfully pushed, or should I just add a short timeout and hope for the best? Don't want to slow things down too much

If you are using a different template and have access to the <head>, couldn't you just set the fav icon manually....
```<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="<http://example.com/favicon.ico>" />```

Maybe i'm over simplifying it, but ideally, you'd set that as needed on a page by page basis in the HTML and not in JS for the exact reasons you were calling out, because that JS only runs when you are on the page and when pages are bookmarked, etc, the fav icons won't update properly.

I haven't specifically used that push function, so i'm not 100% certain, but I would put a timeout regardless. If HubSpot is ever having an issue (or any api for that matter), you don't want to leave your users stuck on a given page just because a push notification failed. I typically put a 10-15 second timeout on anything like this. That's a really long time in web terms and if any type of basic push notification takes that long, something has gone terribly wrong IMO and the user should just move on with their journey.

The first step in troubleshooting events is to inspect the network tab of your browser and look for a pixel called `ptq.gif`.  If that fires, then you are most likely good to go and itâ€™s just taking a bit to process it.  Usually you can also go to the events area in your portal and look at the Activity Log of the event (it should show up in the dashboard)
